Blog
  • Dear Museum of Chinese in America October 15, 2014
    Earlier this month, I visited your museum for a second time. My first visit was three years ago, and during that visit I noticed an error on one of your plaques honoring a notable Chinese-American. At that time, I brought attention of the mistake to someone at the front desk as well as sent an e-mail (to info@ and archives@mocanyc.org); unfortunately, I never heard back from anyone. Further unfortunately, I was disappointed to see the error had not been fixed three years later.

  • Interesting Things October 15, 2014
    This guy is playing my favorite Scott Joplin Rag (Pine Apple Rag), and he's doing it on an /accordion/. It's so good! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EOUdwurfvxY
  • Untitled October 15, 2014

  • Train Love Story October 15, 2014
    Why do you love me in the rain?
  • Yellow Bird and Tortoise October 15, 2014

    Once, there was a yellow bird who lived in a small pet store in Greenwich Village. Like all the animals in the store, he longed for a human to take him home. After all, there was something different about being taken care of by an owner rather than Petco staff; the bird, like all the other animals, longed for human love.

  • Dragon Origami October 15, 2014

    Finally finished the cat. Also took some pics of the dragon I did this summer. That dragon was incredibly hard to make because my origami book didn't have an entry for dragons, so I had to use the Korean instructions. I kinda made up my own way of making it, but I think it looks good. It has a swirly... swirl thing around it's snake like body, and a plastic pearl in its mouth. It's really fragile, so I'll probably not make it again.

  • Female Skaters? October 15, 2014
    Samantha Cesario's fourth place program at Skate America (underscored, which is one reason why I don't like figure skating [your marks are often based off your reputation]): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MA6YgGOR50I
  • Bai Yawen October 15, 2014

    Everything here is pretty much perfection (excluding the step on dismount). Bai Yawen's leaps are textbook. Her acrobatic elements are a bit weaker, but it's really refreshing to see an athlete with such flexibility and toe point.
